trans-unit.source: The Cortana Analytics Process in action: using SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: The Cortana Analytics Process in action: using SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Advanced Analytics Process and Technology in Action
trans-unit.target: Advanced Analytics Process and Technology in Action

trans-unit.source: The Cortana Analytics Process in action: using SQL Data Warehouse
trans-unit.target: The Cortana Analytics Process in action: using SQL Data Warehouse

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we walk you through building and deploying a machine learning model using SQL Data Warehouse (SQL DW) for a publicly available dataset -- the [NYC Taxi Trips](http://www.andresmh.com/nyctaxitrips/) dataset.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we walk you through building and deploying a machine learning model using SQL Data Warehouse (SQL DW) for a publicly available dataset -- the [NYC Taxi Trips](http://www.andresmh.com/nyctaxitrips/) dataset.

trans-unit.source: The binary classification model constructed predicts whether or not a tip is paid for a trip, and models for multiclass classification and regression are also discussed that predict the distribution for the tip amounts paid.
trans-unit.target: The binary classification model constructed predicts whether or not a tip is paid for a trip, and models for multiclass classification and regression are also discussed that predict the distribution for the tip amounts paid.

trans-unit.source: The procedure follows the [Cortana Analytics Process (CAP)](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/learning-paths/cortana-analytics-process/) workflow.
trans-unit.target: The procedure follows the [Cortana Analytics Process (CAP)](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/learning-paths/cortana-analytics-process/) workflow.

trans-unit.source: We show how to setup a data science environment, how to load the data into SQL DW, and how use either SQL DW or an IPython Notebook to explore the data and engineer features to model.
trans-unit.target: We show how to setup a data science environment, how to load the data into SQL DW, and how use either SQL DW or an IPython Notebook to explore the data and engineer features to model.

trans-unit.source: We then show how to build and deploy a model with Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: We then show how to build and deploy a model with Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: The NYC Taxi Trips dataset
trans-unit.target: The NYC Taxi Trips dataset

trans-unit.source: The NYC Taxi Trip data consists of about 20GB of compressed CSV files (~48GB uncompressed), recording more than 173 million individual trips and the fares paid for each trip.
trans-unit.target: The NYC Taxi Trip data consists of about 20GB of compressed CSV files (~48GB uncompressed), recording more than 173 million individual trips and the fares paid for each trip.

trans-unit.source: Each trip record includes the pickup and drop-off locations and times, anonymized hack (driver's) license number, and the medallion (taxi’s unique id) number.
trans-unit.target: Each trip record includes the pickup and drop-off locations and times, anonymized hack (driver's) license number, and the medallion (taxi’s unique id) number.

trans-unit.source: The data covers all trips in the year 2013 and is provided in the following two datasets for each month:
trans-unit.target: The data covers all trips in the year 2013 and is provided in the following two datasets for each month:

trans-unit.source: The **trip_data.csv** file contains trip details, such as number of passengers, pickup and dropoff points, trip duration, and trip length.
trans-unit.target: The **trip_data.csv** file contains trip details, such as number of passengers, pickup and dropoff points, trip duration, and trip length.

trans-unit.source: Here are a few sample records:
trans-unit.target: Here are a few sample records:

trans-unit.source: The **trip_fare.csv** file contains details of the fare paid for each trip, such as payment type, fare amount, surcharge and taxes, tips and tolls, and the total amount paid.
trans-unit.target: The **trip_fare.csv** file contains details of the fare paid for each trip, such as payment type, fare amount, surcharge and taxes, tips and tolls, and the total amount paid.

trans-unit.source: Here are a few sample records:
trans-unit.target: Here are a few sample records:

trans-unit.source: The **unique key** used to join trip\_data and trip\_fare is composed of the following three fields:
trans-unit.target: The **unique key** used to join trip\_data and trip\_fare is composed of the following three fields:

trans-unit.source: medallion,
trans-unit.target: medallion,

trans-unit.source: hack\_license and
trans-unit.target: hack\_license and

trans-unit.source: pickup\_datetime.
trans-unit.target: pickup\_datetime.

trans-unit.source: Address three types of prediction tasks
trans-unit.target: Address three types of prediction tasks

trans-unit.source: We formulate three prediction problems based on the *tip\_amount* to illustrate three kinds of modeling tasks:
trans-unit.target: We formulate three prediction problems based on the *tip\_amount* to illustrate three kinds of modeling tasks:

trans-unit.source: **Binary classification**: To predict whether or not a tip was paid for a trip, i.e. a *tip\_amount* that is greater than $0 is a positive example, while a *tip\_amount* of $0 is a negative example.
trans-unit.target: **Binary classification**: To predict whether or not a tip was paid for a trip, i.e. a *tip\_amount* that is greater than $0 is a positive example, while a *tip\_amount* of $0 is a negative example.

trans-unit.source: **Multiclass classification**: To predict the range of tip paid for the trip.
trans-unit.target: **Multiclass classification**: To predict the range of tip paid for the trip.

trans-unit.source: We divide the *tip\_amount* into five bins or classes:
trans-unit.target: We divide the *tip\_amount* into five bins or classes:

trans-unit.source: **Regression task**: To predict the amount of tip paid for a trip.
trans-unit.target: **Regression task**: To predict the amount of tip paid for a trip.

trans-unit.source: Set up the Azure data science environment for advanced analytics
trans-unit.target: Set up the Azure data science environment for advanced analytics

trans-unit.source: To set up your Azure Data Science environment, follow these steps.
trans-unit.target: To set up your Azure Data Science environment, follow these steps.

trans-unit.source: **Create your own Azure blob storage account**
trans-unit.target: **Create your own Azure blob storage account**

trans-unit.source: When you provision your own Azure blob storage, choose a geo-location for your Azure blob storage in or as close as possible to **South Central US**, which is where the NYC Taxi data is stored.
trans-unit.target: When you provision your own Azure blob storage, choose a geo-location for your Azure blob storage in or as close as possible to **South Central US**, which is where the NYC Taxi data is stored.

trans-unit.source: The data will be copied using AzCopy from the public blob storage container to a container in your own storage account.
trans-unit.target: The data will be copied using AzCopy from the public blob storage container to a container in your own storage account.

trans-unit.source: The closer your Azure blob storage is to South Central US, the faster this task (Step 4) will be completed.
trans-unit.target: The closer your Azure blob storage is to South Central US, the faster this task (Step 4) will be completed.

trans-unit.source: To create your own Azure storage account, follow the steps outlined at [About Azure storage accounts](storage-create-storage-account.md).
trans-unit.target: To create your own Azure storage account, follow the steps outlined at [About Azure storage accounts](storage-create-storage-account.md).

trans-unit.source: Be sure to make notes on the values for following storage account credentials as they will be needed later in this walkthrough.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to make notes on the values for following storage account credentials as they will be needed later in this walkthrough.

trans-unit.source: **Storage Account Name**
trans-unit.target: **Storage Account Name**

trans-unit.source: **Storage Account Key**
trans-unit.target: **Storage Account Key**

trans-unit.source: **Container Name** (which you want the data to be stored in the Azure blob storage)
trans-unit.target: **Container Name** (which you want the data to be stored in the Azure blob storage)

trans-unit.source: **Provision your Azure SQL DW instance.** Follow the documentation at [Create a SQL Data Warehouse](sql-data-warehouse-get-started-provision.md) to provision a SQL Data Warehouse instance.
trans-unit.target: **Provision your Azure SQL DW instance.** Follow the documentation at [Create a SQL Data Warehouse](sql-data-warehouse-get-started-provision.md) to provision a SQL Data Warehouse instance.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that you make notations on the following SQL Data Warehouse credentials which will be used in later steps.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that you make notations on the following SQL Data Warehouse credentials which will be used in later steps.

trans-unit.source: **Server Name**: <server Name>.database.windows.net
trans-unit.target: **Server Name**: <server Name>.database.windows.net

trans-unit.source: **SQLDW (Database) Name**
trans-unit.target: **SQLDW (Database) Name**

trans-unit.source: **Username**
trans-unit.target: **Username**

trans-unit.source: **Password**
trans-unit.target: **Password**

trans-unit.source: **Install Visual Studio 2015 and SQL Server Data Tools.** For instructions, see [Install Visual Studio 2015 and/or SSDT (SQL Server Data Tools) for SQL Data Warehouse](sql-data-warehouse-install-visual-studio.md).
trans-unit.target: **Install Visual Studio 2015 and SQL Server Data Tools.** For instructions, see [Install Visual Studio 2015 and/or SSDT (SQL Server Data Tools) for SQL Data Warehouse](sql-data-warehouse-install-visual-studio.md).

trans-unit.source: **Connect to your Azure SQL DW with Visual Studio.** For instructions, see steps 1 & 2 in [Connect to Azure SQL Data Warehouse with Visual Studio](sql-data-warehouse-get-started-connect.md).
trans-unit.target: **Connect to your Azure SQL DW with Visual Studio.** For instructions, see steps 1 & 2 in [Connect to Azure SQL Data Warehouse with Visual Studio](sql-data-warehouse-get-started-connect.md).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Run the following SQL query on the database you created in your SQL Data Warehouse (instead of the query provided in step 3 of the connect topic,) to **create a master key**.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Run the following SQL query on the database you created in your SQL Data Warehouse (instead of the query provided in step 3 of the connect topic,) to **create a master key**.

trans-unit.source: **Create an Azure Machine Learning workspace under your Azure subscription.** For instructions, see [Create an Azure Machine Learning workspace](machine-learning-create-workspace.md).
trans-unit.target: **Create an Azure Machine Learning workspace under your Azure subscription.** For instructions, see [Create an Azure Machine Learning workspace](machine-learning-create-workspace.md).

trans-unit.source: Load the data into SQL Data Warehouse
trans-unit.target: Load the data into SQL Data Warehouse

trans-unit.source: Open a Windows PowerShell command console.
trans-unit.target: Open a Windows PowerShell command console.

trans-unit.source: Run the following PowerShell commands to download the example SQL script files that we share with you on Github to a local directory that you specify with the parameter *-DestDir*.
trans-unit.target: Run the following PowerShell commands to download the example SQL script files that we share with you on Github to a local directory that you specify with the parameter *-DestDir*.

trans-unit.source: You can change the value of parameter *-DestDir* to any local directory.
trans-unit.target: You can change the value of parameter *-DestDir* to any local directory.

trans-unit.source: If *-DestDir* does not exist, it will be created by the PowerShell script.
trans-unit.target: If *-DestDir* does not exist, it will be created by the PowerShell script.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You might need to **Run as Administrator** when executing the following PowerShell script if your *DestDir* directory needs Administrator privilege to create or to write to it.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You might need to **Run as Administrator** when executing the following PowerShell script if your *DestDir* directory needs Administrator privilege to create or to write to it.

trans-unit.source: After successful execution, your current working directory changes to *-DestDir*.
trans-unit.target: After successful execution, your current working directory changes to *-DestDir*.

trans-unit.source: You should be able to see screen like below:
trans-unit.target: You should be able to see screen like below:

trans-unit.source: In your *-DestDir*, execute the following PowerShell script in administrator mode:
trans-unit.target: In your *-DestDir*, execute the following PowerShell script in administrator mode:

trans-unit.source: When the PowerShell script runs for the first time, you will be asked to input the information from your Azure SQL DW and your Azure blob storage account.
trans-unit.target: When the PowerShell script runs for the first time, you will be asked to input the information from your Azure SQL DW and your Azure blob storage account.

trans-unit.source: When this PowerShell script completes running for the first time, the credentials you input will have been written to a configuration file SQLDW.conf in the present working directory.
trans-unit.target: When this PowerShell script completes running for the first time, the credentials you input will have been written to a configuration file SQLDW.conf in the present working directory.

trans-unit.source: The future run of this PowerShell script file has the option to read all needed parameters from this configuration file.
trans-unit.target: The future run of this PowerShell script file has the option to read all needed parameters from this configuration file.

trans-unit.source: If you need to change some parameters, you can choose to input the parameters on the screen upon prompt by deleting this configuration file and inputting the parameters values as prompted or to change the parameter values by editing the SQLDW.conf file in your *-DestDir* directory.
trans-unit.target: If you need to change some parameters, you can choose to input the parameters on the screen upon prompt by deleting this configuration file and inputting the parameters values as prompted or to change the parameter values by editing the SQLDW.conf file in your *-DestDir* directory.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] In order to avoid schema name conflicts with those that already exist in your Azure SQL DW, when reading parameters directly from the SQLDW.conf file, a 3-digit random number is added to the schema name from the SQLDW.conf file as the default schema name for each run.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] In order to avoid schema name conflicts with those that already exist in your Azure SQL DW, when reading parameters directly from the SQLDW.conf file, a 3-digit random number is added to the schema name from the SQLDW.conf file as the default schema name for each run.

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell script may prompt you for a schema name: the name may be specified at user discretion.
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell script may prompt you for a schema name: the name may be specified at user discretion.

trans-unit.source: This **PowerShell script** file completes the following tasks:
trans-unit.target: This **PowerShell script** file completes the following tasks:

trans-unit.source: **Downloads and installs AzCopy**, if AzCopy is not already installed
trans-unit.target: **Downloads and installs AzCopy**, if AzCopy is not already installed

trans-unit.source: **Copies data to your private blob storage account** from the public blob with AzCopy
trans-unit.target: **Copies data to your private blob storage account** from the public blob with AzCopy

trans-unit.source: **Loads data using Polybase (by executing LoadDataToSQLDW.sql) to your Azure SQL DW** from your private blob storage account with the following commands.
trans-unit.target: **Loads data using Polybase (by executing LoadDataToSQLDW.sql) to your Azure SQL DW** from your private blob storage account with the following commands.

trans-unit.source: Create a schema
trans-unit.target: Create a schema

trans-unit.source: Create a database scoped credential
trans-unit.target: Create a database scoped credential

trans-unit.source: Create an external data source for an Azure storage blob
trans-unit.target: Create an external data source for an Azure storage blob

trans-unit.source: Create an external file format for a csv file.
trans-unit.target: Create an external file format for a csv file.

trans-unit.source: Data is uncompressed and fields are separated with the pipe character.
trans-unit.target: Data is uncompressed and fields are separated with the pipe character.

trans-unit.source: Create external fare and trip tables for NYC taxi dataset in Azure blob storage.
trans-unit.target: Create external fare and trip tables for NYC taxi dataset in Azure blob storage.

trans-unit.source: Load data from external tables in Azure blob storage to SQL Data Warehouse
trans-unit.target: Load data from external tables in Azure blob storage to SQL Data Warehouse

trans-unit.source: Create a sample data table (NYCTaxi_Sample) and insert data to it from selecting SQL queries on the trip and fare tables.
trans-unit.target: Create a sample data table (NYCTaxi_Sample) and insert data to it from selecting SQL queries on the trip and fare tables.

trans-unit.source: (Some steps of this walkthrough needs to use this sample table.)
trans-unit.target: (Some steps of this walkthrough needs to use this sample table.)

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Depending on the geographical location of your private blob storage account, the process of copying data from a public blob to your private storage account can take about 15 minutes, or even longer,and the process of loading data from your storage account to your Azure SQL DW could take 20 minutes or longer.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Depending on the geographical location of your private blob storage account, the process of copying data from a public blob to your private storage account can take about 15 minutes, or even longer,and the process of loading data from your storage account to your Azure SQL DW could take 20 minutes or longer.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If the .csv files to be copied from the public blob storage to your private blob storage account already exist in your private blob storage account, AzCopy will ask you whether you want to overwrite them.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If the .csv files to be copied from the public blob storage to your private blob storage account already exist in your private blob storage account, AzCopy will ask you whether you want to overwrite them.

trans-unit.source: If you do not want to overwrite them, input **n** when prompted.
trans-unit.target: If you do not want to overwrite them, input **n** when prompted.

trans-unit.source: If you want to overwrite **all** of them, input **a** when prompted.
trans-unit.target: If you want to overwrite **all** of them, input **a** when prompted.

trans-unit.source: You can also input **y** to overwrite .csv files individually.
trans-unit.target: You can also input **y** to overwrite .csv files individually.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] **Use your own data:** If your data is in your on-premise machine in your real life application, you can still use AzCopy to upload on-premise data to your private Azure blob storage.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] **Use your own data:** If your data is in your on-premise machine in your real life application, you can still use AzCopy to upload on-premise data to your private Azure blob storage.

trans-unit.source: You only need to change the **Source** location, `$Source = "http://getgoing.blob.core.windows.net/public/nyctaxidataset"`, in the AzCopy command of the PowerShell script file to the local directory that contains your data.
trans-unit.target: You only need to change the **Source** location, `$Source = "http://getgoing.blob.core.windows.net/public/nyctaxidataset"`, in the AzCopy command of the PowerShell script file to the local directory that contains your data.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] If your data is already in your private Azure blob storage in your real life application, you can skip the AzCopy step in the PowerShell script and directly upload the data to Azure SQL DW.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] If your data is already in your private Azure blob storage in your real life application, you can skip the AzCopy step in the PowerShell script and directly upload the data to Azure SQL DW.

trans-unit.source: This will require additional edits of the script to tailor it to the format of your data.
trans-unit.target: This will require additional edits of the script to tailor it to the format of your data.

trans-unit.source: This Powershell script also plugs in the Azure SQL DW information into the data exploration example files SQLDW_Explorations.sql, SQLDW_Explorations.ipynb, and SQLDW_Explorations_Scripts.py so that these three files are ready to be tried out instantly after the PowerShell script completes.
trans-unit.target: This Powershell script also plugs in the Azure SQL DW information into the data exploration example files SQLDW_Explorations.sql, SQLDW_Explorations.ipynb, and SQLDW_Explorations_Scripts.py so that these three files are ready to be tried out instantly after the PowerShell script completes.

trans-unit.source: After a successful execution, you will see screen like below:
trans-unit.target: After a successful execution, you will see screen like below:

trans-unit.source: Data exploration and feature engineering in Azure SQL Data Warehouse
trans-unit.target: Data exploration and feature engineering in Azure SQL Data Warehouse

trans-unit.source: In this section, we perform data exploration and feature generation by running SQL queries against Azure SQL DW directly using **Visual Studio Data Tools**.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we perform data exploration and feature generation by running SQL queries against Azure SQL DW directly using **Visual Studio Data Tools**.

trans-unit.source: All SQL queries used in this section can be found in the sample script named *SQLDW_Explorations.sql*.
trans-unit.target: All SQL queries used in this section can be found in the sample script named *SQLDW_Explorations.sql*.

trans-unit.source: This file has already been downloaded to your local directory by the PowerShell script.
trans-unit.target: This file has already been downloaded to your local directory by the PowerShell script.

trans-unit.source: You can also retrieve it from [Github](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/master/Misc/SQLDW/SQLDW_Explorations.sql).
trans-unit.target: You can also retrieve it from [Github](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/master/Misc/SQLDW/SQLDW_Explorations.sql).

trans-unit.source: But the file in Github does not have the Azure SQL DW information plugged in.
trans-unit.target: But the file in Github does not have the Azure SQL DW information plugged in.

trans-unit.source: Connect to your Azure SQL DW using Visual Studio with the SQL DW login name and password and open up the **SQL Object Explorer** to confirm the database and tables have been imported.
trans-unit.target: Connect to your Azure SQL DW using Visual Studio with the SQL DW login name and password and open up the **SQL Object Explorer** to confirm the database and tables have been imported.

trans-unit.source: Retrieve the *SQLDW_Explorations.sql* file.
trans-unit.target: Retrieve the *SQLDW_Explorations.sql* file.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To open a Parallel Data Warehouse (PDW) query editor, use the **New Query** command while your PDW is selected in the **SQL Object Explorer**.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To open a Parallel Data Warehouse (PDW) query editor, use the **New Query** command while your PDW is selected in the **SQL Object Explorer**.

trans-unit.source: The standard SQL query editor is not supported by PDW.
trans-unit.target: The standard SQL query editor is not supported by PDW.

trans-unit.source: Here are the type of data exploration and feature generation tasks performed in this section:
trans-unit.target: Here are the type of data exploration and feature generation tasks performed in this section:

trans-unit.source: Explore data distributions of a few fields in varying time windows.
trans-unit.target: Explore data distributions of a few fields in varying time windows.

trans-unit.source: Investigate data quality of the longitude and latitude fields.
trans-unit.target: Investigate data quality of the longitude and latitude fields.

trans-unit.source: Generate binary and multiclass classification labels based on the **tip\_amount**.
trans-unit.target: Generate binary and multiclass classification labels based on the **tip\_amount**.

trans-unit.source: Generate features and compute/compare trip distances.
trans-unit.target: Generate features and compute/compare trip distances.

trans-unit.source: Join the two tables and extract a random sample that will be used to build models.
trans-unit.target: Join the two tables and extract a random sample that will be used to build models.

trans-unit.source: Data import verification
trans-unit.target: Data import verification

trans-unit.source: These queries provide a quick verification of the number of rows and columns in the tables populated earlier using Polybase's parallel bulk import,
trans-unit.target: These queries provide a quick verification of the number of rows and columns in the tables populated earlier using Polybase's parallel bulk import,

trans-unit.source: **Output:** You should get 173,179,759 rows and 14 columns.
trans-unit.target: **Output:** You should get 173,179,759 rows and 14 columns.

trans-unit.source: Exploration: Trip distribution by medallion
trans-unit.target: Exploration: Trip distribution by medallion

trans-unit.source: This example query identifies the medallions (taxi numbers) that completed more than 100 trips within a specified time period.
trans-unit.target: This example query identifies the medallions (taxi numbers) that completed more than 100 trips within a specified time period.

trans-unit.source: The query would benefit from the partitioned table access since it is conditioned by the partition scheme of **pickup\_datetime**.
trans-unit.target: The query would benefit from the partitioned table access since it is conditioned by the partition scheme of **pickup\_datetime**.

trans-unit.source: Querying the full dataset will also make use of the partitioned table and/or index scan.
trans-unit.target: Querying the full dataset will also make use of the partitioned table and/or index scan.

trans-unit.source: **Output:** The query should return a table with rows specifying the 13,369 medallions (taxis) and the number of trip completed by them in 2013.
trans-unit.target: **Output:** The query should return a table with rows specifying the 13,369 medallions (taxis) and the number of trip completed by them in 2013.

trans-unit.source: The last column contains the count of the number of trips completed.
trans-unit.target: The last column contains the count of the number of trips completed.

trans-unit.source: Exploration: Trip distribution by medallion and hack_license
trans-unit.target: Exploration: Trip distribution by medallion and hack_license

trans-unit.source: This example identifies the medallions (taxi numbers) and hack_license numbers (drivers) that completed more than 100 trips within a specified time period.
trans-unit.target: This example identifies the medallions (taxi numbers) and hack_license numbers (drivers) that completed more than 100 trips within a specified time period.

trans-unit.source: **Output:** The query should return a table with 13,369 rows specifying the 13,369 car/driver IDs that have completed more that 100 trips in 2013.
trans-unit.target: **Output:** The query should return a table with 13,369 rows specifying the 13,369 car/driver IDs that have completed more that 100 trips in 2013.

trans-unit.source: The last column contains the count of the number of trips completed.
trans-unit.target: The last column contains the count of the number of trips completed.

trans-unit.source: Data quality assessment: Verify records with incorrect longitude and/or latitude
trans-unit.target: Data quality assessment: Verify records with incorrect longitude and/or latitude

trans-unit.source: This example investigates if any of the longitude and/or latitude fields either contain an invalid value (radian degrees should be between -90 and 90), or have (0, 0) coordinates.
trans-unit.target: This example investigates if any of the longitude and/or latitude fields either contain an invalid value (radian degrees should be between -90 and 90), or have (0, 0) coordinates.

trans-unit.source: **Output:** The query returns 837,467 trips that have invalid longitude and/or latitude fields.
trans-unit.target: **Output:** The query returns 837,467 trips that have invalid longitude and/or latitude fields.

trans-unit.source: Exploration: Tipped vs. not tipped trips distribution
trans-unit.target: Exploration: Tipped vs. not tipped trips distribution

trans-unit.source: This example finds the number of trips that were tipped vs. the number that were not tipped in a specified time period (or in the full dataset if covering the full year as it is set up here).
trans-unit.target: This example finds the number of trips that were tipped vs. the number that were not tipped in a specified time period (or in the full dataset if covering the full year as it is set up here).

trans-unit.source: This distribution reflects the binary label distribution to be later used for binary classification modeling.
trans-unit.target: This distribution reflects the binary label distribution to be later used for binary classification modeling.

trans-unit.source: **Output:** The query should return the following tip frequencies for the year 2013: 90,447,622 tipped and 82,264,709 not-tipped.
trans-unit.target: **Output:** The query should return the following tip frequencies for the year 2013: 90,447,622 tipped and 82,264,709 not-tipped.

trans-unit.source: Exploration: Tip class/range distribution
trans-unit.target: Exploration: Tip class/range distribution

trans-unit.source: This example computes the distribution of tip ranges in a given time period (or in the full dataset if covering the full year).
trans-unit.target: This example computes the distribution of tip ranges in a given time period (or in the full dataset if covering the full year).

trans-unit.source: This is the distribution of the label classes that will be used later for multiclass classification modeling.
trans-unit.target: This is the distribution of the label classes that will be used later for multiclass classification modeling.

trans-unit.source: **Output:**
trans-unit.target: **Output:**

trans-unit.source: tip_class
trans-unit.target: tip_class

trans-unit.source: tip_freq
trans-unit.target: tip_freq

trans-unit.source: Exploration: Compute and compare trip distance
trans-unit.target: Exploration: Compute and compare trip distance

trans-unit.source: This example converts the pickup and drop-off longitude and latitude to SQL geography points, computes the trip distance using SQL geography points difference, and returns a random sample of the results for comparison.
trans-unit.target: This example converts the pickup and drop-off longitude and latitude to SQL geography points, computes the trip distance using SQL geography points difference, and returns a random sample of the results for comparison.

trans-unit.source: The example limits the results to valid coordinates only using the data quality assessment query covered earlier.
trans-unit.target: The example limits the results to valid coordinates only using the data quality assessment query covered earlier.

trans-unit.source: Feature engineering using SQL functions
trans-unit.target: Feature engineering using SQL functions

trans-unit.source: Sometimes SQL functions can be an efficient option for feature engineering.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes SQL functions can be an efficient option for feature engineering.

trans-unit.source: In this walkthrough, we defined a SQL function to calculate the direct distance between the pickup and dropoff locations.
trans-unit.target: In this walkthrough, we defined a SQL function to calculate the direct distance between the pickup and dropoff locations.

trans-unit.source: You can run the following SQL scripts in **Visual Studio Data Tools**.
trans-unit.target: You can run the following SQL scripts in **Visual Studio Data Tools**.

trans-unit.target: Here is an example to call this function to generate features in your SQL query:

trans-unit.target: **Output:** This query generates a table (with 2,803,538 rows) with pickup and dropoff latitudes and longitudes and the corresponding direct distances in miles.

trans-unit.source: Prepare data for model building
trans-unit.target: Prepare data for model building

trans-unit.source: The following query joins the **nyctaxi\_trip** and **nyctaxi\_fare** tables, generates a binary classification label **tipped**, a multi-class classification label **tip\_class**, and extracts a sample from the full joined dataset.
trans-unit.target: The following query joins the **nyctaxi\_trip** and **nyctaxi\_fare** tables, generates a binary classification label **tipped**, a multi-class classification label **tip\_class**, and extracts a sample from the full joined dataset.

trans-unit.source: The sampling is done by retrieving a subset of the trips based on pickup time.
trans-unit.target: The sampling is done by retrieving a subset of the trips based on pickup time.

trans-unit.source: This query can be copied then pasted directly in the [Azure Machine Learning Studio](https://studio.azureml.net) [Reader][reader] module for direct data ingestion from the SQL database instance in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This query can be copied then pasted directly in the [Azure Machine Learning Studio](https://studio.azureml.net) [Reader][reader] module for direct data ingestion from the SQL database instance in Azure.

trans-unit.source: The query excludes records with incorrect (0, 0) coordinates.
trans-unit.target: The query excludes records with incorrect (0, 0) coordinates.

trans-unit.source: When you are ready to proceed to Azure Machine Learning, you may either:
trans-unit.target: When you are ready to proceed to Azure Machine Learning, you may either:

trans-unit.source: Save the final SQL query to extract and sample the data and copy-paste the query directly into a [Reader][reader] module in Azure Machine Learning, or
trans-unit.target: Save the final SQL query to extract and sample the data and copy-paste the query directly into a [Reader][reader] module in Azure Machine Learning, or

trans-unit.source: Persist the sampled and engineered data you plan to use for model building in a new SQL DW table and use the new table in the [Reader][reader] module in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: Persist the sampled and engineered data you plan to use for model building in a new SQL DW table and use the new table in the [Reader][reader] module in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell script in earlier step has done this for you.
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell script in earlier step has done this for you.

trans-unit.source: You can read directly from this table in the Reader module.
trans-unit.target: You can read directly from this table in the Reader module.

trans-unit.source: Data exploration and feature engineering in IPython notebook
trans-unit.target: Data exploration and feature engineering in IPython notebook

trans-unit.source: In this section, we will perform data exploration and feature generation using both Python and SQL queries against the SQL DW created earlier.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we will perform data exploration and feature generation using both Python and SQL queries against the SQL DW created earlier.

trans-unit.source: A sample IPython notebook named **SQLDW_Explorations.ipynb** and a Python script file **SQLDW_Explorations_Scripts.py** have been downloaded to your local directory.
trans-unit.target: A sample IPython notebook named **SQLDW_Explorations.ipynb** and a Python script file **SQLDW_Explorations_Scripts.py** have been downloaded to your local directory.

trans-unit.source: They are also available on [GitHub](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/tree/master/Misc/SQLDW).
trans-unit.target: They are also available on [GitHub](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/tree/master/Misc/SQLDW).

trans-unit.source: These two files are identical in Python scripts.
trans-unit.target: These two files are identical in Python scripts.

trans-unit.source: The Python script file is provided to you in case you do not have an IPython Notebook server.
trans-unit.target: The Python script file is provided to you in case you do not have an IPython Notebook server.

trans-unit.source: These two sample Python files are designed under **Python 2.7**.
trans-unit.target: These two sample Python files are designed under **Python 2.7**.

trans-unit.source: The needed Azure SQL DW information in the sample IPython Notebook and the Python script file downloaded to your local machine has been plugged in by the PowerShell script previously.
trans-unit.target: The needed Azure SQL DW information in the sample IPython Notebook and the Python script file downloaded to your local machine has been plugged in by the PowerShell script previously.

trans-unit.source: They are executable without any modification.
trans-unit.target: They are executable without any modification.

trans-unit.source: If you have already set up an AzureML workspace, you can directly upload the sample IPython Notebook to the AzureML IPython Notebook service and start running it.
trans-unit.target: If you have already set up an AzureML workspace, you can directly upload the sample IPython Notebook to the AzureML IPython Notebook service and start running it.

trans-unit.source: Here are the steps to upload to AzureML IPython Notebook service:
trans-unit.target: Here are the steps to upload to AzureML IPython Notebook service:

trans-unit.source: Log in to your AzureML workspace, click "Studio" at the top, and click "NOTEBOOKS" on the left side of the web page.
trans-unit.target: Log in to your AzureML workspace, click "Studio" at the top, and click "NOTEBOOKS" on the left side of the web page.

trans-unit.source: Click "NEW" on the left bottom corner of the web page, and select "Python 2".
trans-unit.target: Click "NEW" on the left bottom corner of the web page, and select "Python 2".

trans-unit.source: Then, provide a name to the notebook and click the check mark to create the new blank IPython Notebook.
trans-unit.target: Then, provide a name to the notebook and click the check mark to create the new blank IPython Notebook.

trans-unit.source: Click the "Jupyter" symbol on the left top corner of the new IPython Notebook.
trans-unit.target: Click the "Jupyter" symbol on the left top corner of the new IPython Notebook.

trans-unit.source: Drag and drop the sample IPython Notebook to the **tree** page of your AzureML IPython Notebook service, and click **Upload**.
trans-unit.target: Drag and drop the sample IPython Notebook to the **tree** page of your AzureML IPython Notebook service, and click **Upload**.

trans-unit.source: Then, the sample IPython Notebook will be uploaded to the AzureML IPython Notebook service.
trans-unit.target: Then, the sample IPython Notebook will be uploaded to the AzureML IPython Notebook service.

trans-unit.source: In order to run the sample IPython Notebook or the Python script file, the following Python packages are needed.
trans-unit.target: In order to run the sample IPython Notebook or the Python script file, the following Python packages are needed.

trans-unit.source: If you are using the AzureML IPython Notebook service, these packages have been pre-installed.
trans-unit.target: If you are using the AzureML IPython Notebook service, these packages have been pre-installed.

trans-unit.source: The recommended sequence when building advanced analytical solutions on AzureML with large data is the following:
trans-unit.target: The recommended sequence when building advanced analytical solutions on AzureML with large data is the following:

trans-unit.source: Read in a small sample of the data into an in-memory data frame.
trans-unit.target: Read in a small sample of the data into an in-memory data frame.

trans-unit.source: Perform some visualizations and explorations using the sampled data.
trans-unit.target: Perform some visualizations and explorations using the sampled data.

trans-unit.source: Experiment with feature engineering using the sampled data.
trans-unit.target: Experiment with feature engineering using the sampled data.

trans-unit.source: For larger data exploration, data manipulation and feature engineering, use Python to issue SQL Queries directly against the SQL DW.
trans-unit.target: For larger data exploration, data manipulation and feature engineering, use Python to issue SQL Queries directly against the SQL DW.

trans-unit.source: Decide the sample size to be suitable for Azure Machine Learning model building.
trans-unit.target: Decide the sample size to be suitable for Azure Machine Learning model building.

trans-unit.target: The followings are a few data exploration, data visualization, and feature engineering examples.

trans-unit.source: More data explorations can be found in the sample IPython Notebook and the sample Python script file.
trans-unit.target: More data explorations can be found in the sample IPython Notebook and the sample Python script file.

trans-unit.source: Build models in Azure Machine Learning
trans-unit.target: Build models in Azure Machine Learning

trans-unit.source: We are now ready to proceed to model building and model deployment in [Azure Machine Learning](https://studio.azureml.net).
trans-unit.target: We are now ready to proceed to model building and model deployment in [Azure Machine Learning](https://studio.azureml.net).

trans-unit.source: The data is ready to be used in any of the prediction problems identified earlier, namely:
trans-unit.target: The data is ready to be used in any of the prediction problems identified earlier, namely:

trans-unit.source: **Binary classification**: To predict whether or not a tip was paid for a trip.
trans-unit.target: **Binary classification**: To predict whether or not a tip was paid for a trip.

trans-unit.source: **Multiclass classification**: To predict the range of tip paid, according to the previously defined classes.
trans-unit.target: **Multiclass classification**: To predict the range of tip paid, according to the previously defined classes.

trans-unit.source: **Regression task**: To predict the amount of tip paid for a trip.
trans-unit.target: **Regression task**: To predict the amount of tip paid for a trip.

trans-unit.source: To begin the modeling exercise, log in to your **Azure Machine Learning** workspace.
trans-unit.target: To begin the modeling exercise, log in to your **Azure Machine Learning** workspace.

trans-unit.source: If you have not yet created a machine learning workspace, see [Create an Azure ML workspace](machine-learning-create-workspace.md).
trans-unit.target: If you have not yet created a machine learning workspace, see [Create an Azure ML workspace](machine-learning-create-workspace.md).

trans-unit.source: To get started with Azure Machine Learning, see [What is Azure Machine Learning Studio?](machine-learning-what-is-ml-studio.md)
trans-unit.target: To get started with Azure Machine Learning, see [What is Azure Machine Learning Studio?](machine-learning-what-is-ml-studio.md)

trans-unit.source: Log in to [Azure Machine Learning Studio](https://studio.azureml.net).
trans-unit.target: Log in to [Azure Machine Learning Studio](https://studio.azureml.net).

trans-unit.source: The Studio Home page provides a wealth of information, videos, tutorials, links to the Modules Reference, and other resources.
trans-unit.target: The Studio Home page provides a wealth of information, videos, tutorials, links to the Modules Reference, and other resources.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Azure Machine Learning, consult the [Azure Machine Learning Documentation Center](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/machine-learning/).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure Machine Learning, consult the [Azure Machine Learning Documentation Center](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/machine-learning/).

trans-unit.source: A typical training experiment consists of the following steps:
trans-unit.target: A typical training experiment consists of the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Create a **+NEW** experiment.
trans-unit.target: Create a **+NEW** experiment.

trans-unit.source: Get the data into Azure ML.
trans-unit.target: Get the data into Azure ML.

trans-unit.source: Pre-process, transform and manipulate the data as needed.
trans-unit.target: Pre-process, transform and manipulate the data as needed.

trans-unit.source: Generate features as needed.
trans-unit.target: Generate features as needed.

trans-unit.source: Split the data into training/validation/testing datasets(or have separate datasets for each).
trans-unit.target: Split the data into training/validation/testing datasets(or have separate datasets for each).

trans-unit.source: Select one or more machine learning algorithms depending on the learning problem to solve.
trans-unit.target: Select one or more machine learning algorithms depending on the learning problem to solve.

trans-unit.source: E.g., binary classification, multiclass classification, regression.
trans-unit.target: E.g., binary classification, multiclass classification, regression.

trans-unit.source: Train one or more models using the training dataset.
trans-unit.target: Train one or more models using the training dataset.

trans-unit.source: Score the validation dataset using the trained model(s).
trans-unit.target: Score the validation dataset using the trained model(s).

trans-unit.source: Evaluate the model(s) to compute the relevant metrics for the learning problem.
trans-unit.target: Evaluate the model(s) to compute the relevant metrics for the learning problem.

trans-unit.source: Fine tune the model(s) and select the best model to deploy.
trans-unit.target: Fine tune the model(s) and select the best model to deploy.

trans-unit.source: In this exercise, we have already explored and engineered the data in SQL Data Warehouse, and decided on the sample size to ingest in Azure ML.
trans-unit.target: In this exercise, we have already explored and engineered the data in SQL Data Warehouse, and decided on the sample size to ingest in Azure ML.

trans-unit.source: Here is the procedure to build one or more of the prediction models:
trans-unit.target: Here is the procedure to build one or more of the prediction models:

trans-unit.source: Get the data into Azure ML using the [Reader][reader] module, available in the **Data Input and Output** section.
trans-unit.target: Get the data into Azure ML using the [Reader][reader] module, available in the **Data Input and Output** section.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the [Reader][reader] module reference page.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the [Reader][reader] module reference page.

trans-unit.source: ![Azure ML Reader][17]
trans-unit.target: ![Azure ML Reader][17]

trans-unit.source: Select **Azure SQL Database** as the **Data source** in the **Properties** panel.
trans-unit.target: Select **Azure SQL Database** as the **Data source** in the **Properties** panel.

trans-unit.source: Enter the database DNS name in the **Database server name** field.
trans-unit.target: Enter the database DNS name in the **Database server name** field.

trans-unit.source: Format: `tcp:<your_virtual_machine_DNS_name>,1433`
trans-unit.target: Format: `tcp:<your_virtual_machine_DNS_name>,1433`

trans-unit.source: Enter the **Database name** in the corresponding field.
trans-unit.target: Enter the **Database name** in the corresponding field.

trans-unit.source: Enter the *SQL user name* in the **Server user account name**, and the *password* in the **Server user account password**.
trans-unit.target: Enter the *SQL user name* in the **Server user account name**, and the *password* in the **Server user account password**.

trans-unit.source: Check the **Accept any server certificate** option.
trans-unit.target: Check the **Accept any server certificate** option.

trans-unit.source: In the **Database query** edit text area, paste the query which extracts the necessary database fields (including any computed fields such as the labels) and down samples the data to the desired sample size.
trans-unit.target: In the **Database query** edit text area, paste the query which extracts the necessary database fields (including any computed fields such as the labels) and down samples the data to the desired sample size.

trans-unit.source: An example of a binary classification experiment reading data directly from the SQL Data Warehouse database is in the figure below (remember to replace the table names nyctaxi_trip and nyctaxi_fare by the schema name and the table names you used in your walkthrough).
trans-unit.target: An example of a binary classification experiment reading data directly from the SQL Data Warehouse database is in the figure below (remember to replace the table names nyctaxi_trip and nyctaxi_fare by the schema name and the table names you used in your walkthrough).

trans-unit.source: Similar experiments can be constructed for multiclass classification and regression problems.
trans-unit.target: Similar experiments can be constructed for multiclass classification and regression problems.

trans-unit.source: ![Azure ML Train][10]
trans-unit.target: ![Azure ML Train][10]

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] In the modeling data extraction and sampling query examples provided in previous sections, **all labels for the three modeling exercises are included in the query**.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] In the modeling data extraction and sampling query examples provided in previous sections, **all labels for the three modeling exercises are included in the query**.

trans-unit.source: An important (required) step in each of the modeling exercises is to **exclude** the unnecessary labels for the other two problems, and any other **target leaks**.
trans-unit.target: An important (required) step in each of the modeling exercises is to **exclude** the unnecessary labels for the other two problems, and any other **target leaks**.

trans-unit.source: For example, when using binary classification, use the label **tipped** and exclude the fields **tip\_class**, **tip\_amount**, and **total\_amount**.
trans-unit.target: For example, when using binary classification, use the label **tipped** and exclude the fields **tip\_class**, **tip\_amount**, and **total\_amount**.

trans-unit.source: The latter are target leaks since they imply the tip paid.
trans-unit.target: The latter are target leaks since they imply the tip paid.

trans-unit.source: To exclude any unnecessary columns or target leaks, you may use the [Project Columns][project-columns] module or the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor].
trans-unit.target: To exclude any unnecessary columns or target leaks, you may use the [Project Columns][project-columns] module or the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor].

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Project Columns][project-columns] and [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] reference pages.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Project Columns][project-columns] and [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] reference pages.

trans-unit.source: Deploy models in Azure Machine Learning
trans-unit.target: Deploy models in Azure Machine Learning

trans-unit.source: When your model is ready, you can easily deploy it as a web service directly from the experiment.
trans-unit.target: When your model is ready, you can easily deploy it as a web service directly from the experiment.

trans-unit.source: For more information about deploying Azure ML web services, see [Deploy an Azure Machine Learning web service](machine-learning-publish-a-machine-learning-web-service.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about deploying Azure ML web services, see [Deploy an Azure Machine Learning web service](machine-learning-publish-a-machine-learning-web-service.md).

trans-unit.source: To deploy a new web service, you need to:
trans-unit.target: To deploy a new web service, you need to:

trans-unit.source: Create a scoring experiment.
trans-unit.target: Create a scoring experiment.

trans-unit.source: Deploy the web service.
trans-unit.target: Deploy the web service.

trans-unit.source: To create a scoring experiment from a **Finished** training experiment, click **CREATE SCORING EXPERIMENT** in the lower action bar.
trans-unit.target: To create a scoring experiment from a **Finished** training experiment, click **CREATE SCORING EXPERIMENT** in the lower action bar.

trans-unit.source: ![Azure Scoring][18]
trans-unit.target: ![Azure Scoring][18]

trans-unit.source: Azure Machine Learning will attempt to create a scoring experiment based on the components of the training experiment.
trans-unit.target: Azure Machine Learning will attempt to create a scoring experiment based on the components of the training experiment.

trans-unit.source: In particular, it will:
trans-unit.target: In particular, it will:

trans-unit.source: Save the trained model and remove the model training modules.
trans-unit.target: Save the trained model and remove the model training modules.

trans-unit.source: Identify a logical **input port** to represent the expected input data schema.
trans-unit.target: Identify a logical **input port** to represent the expected input data schema.

trans-unit.source: Identify a logical **output port** to represent the expected web service output schema.
trans-unit.target: Identify a logical **output port** to represent the expected web service output schema.

trans-unit.source: When the scoring experiment is created, review it and make adjust as needed.
trans-unit.target: When the scoring experiment is created, review it and make adjust as needed.

trans-unit.source: A typical adjustment is to replace the input dataset and/or query with one which excludes label fields, as these will not be available when the service is called.
trans-unit.target: A typical adjustment is to replace the input dataset and/or query with one which excludes label fields, as these will not be available when the service is called.

trans-unit.source: It is also a good practice to reduce the size of the input dataset and/or query to a few records, just enough to indicate the input schema.
trans-unit.target: It is also a good practice to reduce the size of the input dataset and/or query to a few records, just enough to indicate the input schema.

trans-unit.source: For the output port, it is common to exclude all input fields and only include the **Scored Labels** and **Scored Probabilities** in the output using the [Project Columns][project-columns] module.
trans-unit.target: For the output port, it is common to exclude all input fields and only include the **Scored Labels** and **Scored Probabilities** in the output using the [Project Columns][project-columns] module.

trans-unit.source: A sample scoring experiment is provided in the figure below.
trans-unit.target: A sample scoring experiment is provided in the figure below.

trans-unit.source: When ready to deploy, click the **PUBLISH WEB SERVICE** button in the lower action bar.
trans-unit.target: When ready to deploy, click the **PUBLISH WEB SERVICE** button in the lower action bar.

trans-unit.source: ![Azure ML Publish][11]
trans-unit.target: ![Azure ML Publish][11]

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: To recap what we have done in this walkthrough tutorial, you have created an Azure data science environment, worked with a large public dataset, taking it through the Cortana Analytics Process, all the way from data acquisition to model training, and then to the deployment of an Azure Machine Learning web service.
trans-unit.target: To recap what we have done in this walkthrough tutorial, you have created an Azure data science environment, worked with a large public dataset, taking it through the Cortana Analytics Process, all the way from data acquisition to model training, and then to the deployment of an Azure Machine Learning web service.
